title.rendered: New identity for WorldPay Zinc by SomeOne

content.rendered:
Launched at the end of June, WorldPay Zinc is a “Chip & PIN” device — which, as opposed to the common swiping Americans do, is more like an old-school ATM transaction where you insert your card and enter a PIN — that connects via Bluetooth to iPhones, iPads, and Android phones and allows anyone to accept credit card payments wherever they are. Zinc is provided by WorldPay, a UK alternative to PayPal that has been around since 1994, and is trying to compete with the latter’s Here device that also entered the UK market this year. If you are wondering, the obvious and best-in-class Square is not available outside the US and Canada. Positioned more for “Mobile workers, from electricians to window cleaners, beauty therapists to market stall-holders” than service providers or store owners, WorldPay Zinc launched with a new identity designed by London-based SomeOne.

SomeOne was appointed to create the name and visual brand identity which centres around representing the high speed digital payments — represented by high speed photography capturing the moment when two elements meet. […] With this product the magic happens when transactions occur — buyer and seller — two colours coming together. The frozen shots are a rapid unseen moment in time, just like the millions of payments WorldPay process daily. The perfect metaphor for the new service.’ Says SomeOne’s Designer Mark Smith.

The imagery was all shot by photographer Simon Warren — using airborne paint pigment and a high speed photo-rig.

SomeOne case study

Without a clearly designated logo, WorldPay Zinc is identifiable first and foremost by its exploding, colliding duo of colors, a concept that I immediately understood as the point of transaction or the meeting point between order and sale. It’s clever, graphic, and completely unexpected for the device and the online payment industry. The question is: how long can this last? At what point does the exploding pigment visual become too much or too much of the same in application? Right now, at launch, it looks and feels great but my guess is that it will have to evolve or change dramatically in the next two to three years to stay interesting. The other thing that struck me is how more graphically sophisticated the identity is to the actual device, which looks like an old calculator and is as attractive as a 1997 Nokia phone. These videos don’t help sell it too wildly either so it seems like WorldPay Zinc’s identity is a little ahead of its own curve.
